On account of the quick removal of our immense stock from the building to prevent a loss by
fire, and the damage caused thereby, we are now placing our immense
$45,000.00 STOCK OF DRY GOODS, CLOTHING AND SHOES
on sale at an exceedingly low margin. This is an exceptional opportunity offered the buying pub
lic, at a time when the saving cannot be wholly measured in dollars and cents. The insurance
adjuster has made it possible for us to make these low prices; and the $25,000 fire which visited
Springdale gives you an early opportunity to purchase the best goods at the lowest possible prices.

TUNE IN ON
THE FIRE-CHIEF PROGRAM
• TUESDAY NIGHTS, 8:30 WRC N. B. C.
•' •
Today! Now! At every Fire-Chief pump, The Texas Company is again making
gasoline history! With a new Fire-Chief—a Greater Fire-Chief! The 100%
anti-knock "regular”... at no extra price!
You all know the original Fire-Chief. •. how, a
year ago, this great gasoline literally swept the
country!
Well, Fire-Chief is still Fire-Chief! Now, more
than ever before, it surpasses the most rigid
U. S. Government specifications for an "emer
gency* motor fuel! For it’s Fire-Chief plus anti
knock action that will amaze and thrill even the
most jaded driver! Imagine it! Fire-engine power
plus top anti-knock at no extra price! Something
you’ve hoped for but never have been able to
buy in a regular priced gasoline.
Try the Greater Fire-Chief today. Remember,
it’s on sale at all Texaco Fire Chief pumps—at
regular gasoline prices. FLAME-TINTED • • •
for your identification and protection.

SUGAR'S STOCK SCORCHED
Fire, Smoke and Water Take Terrible Toll In
First- Avenue South Conflagration
THE SUGAR CLOTHING CO., 218 FIRST AVENUE SOUTH, HAVE HAD A FIRE-FLAMES, SMOKE AND WATER DAMAGED THEIR STOCK TO THE EXTENT OF
$10,000; THE INSURANCE COMPANIES HAVE PAID THE LOSS AND MR. SUGAR THROWS THE SALVAGE OF THE STOCK TO THE PEOPLE IN A SENSATIONAL
TEN DAYS FIRE SALE
Starting Saturday, Feb. 12th, 1921 at 9. a. m.
THE SALVAGE OF THE SUGAR CLOTHING CO.'S STOCK OF MEN'S CLOTHING, FURNISHING AND SHOES-$10,000 WORTH OF DEPENDABLE MEN'S GOODS

items.title: Imperial Valley press.
note: Archived issues are available in digital format as part of the Library of Congress Chronicling America online collection.
Latest issue consulted: Oct. 7, 1993.
Master negatives are available for duplication from:
Published as: Imperial Valley press and El Centro progress, Jan. 16-Oct. 25, 1922.

Published combined issues on holidays: The morning post-Imperial Valley press, Nov. 28, 1935 and Dec. 25, 1935. On Sundays published as: The Post-press, Jan. 12, 1936-Oct. 30, 1960; Imperial Valley news-press, Nov. 6, 1960-Feb. 26/27, 1967; Imperial Valley press/The Brawley news, Oct. 2, 1988-June 7, 1992; published as combined Sat./Sun. ed., Apr. 29/30, 1961-<Jan 13/14, 1968>
Sunday issues have their own numbering.

Today, now, at every Fite-Chief pump, Flic Texas Company again makes
gasoline history! With a new Fire-Chief— a Greater Fire-Chief! A 1009 b
anti-knock Fire-Chief at no extra price!
You all know the original Fire-Chief ... how, a
year ago, this great gasoline literally took the
country by storm!
Well, Fire-Chief is still Fire-ChieJ! Still sur
passes even the most rigid U. S. Government
specifications for an "emergency” motor fuel!
But now it’s Fire-Cliief plus Anti-knock action
that will amaze and thrill even the most jaded
THE TEXAS COMPANY A
driver! Imagine it! Fire-engine power plus top
anti-knock at no extra price. Something you’ve
hoped for but never before been able to buy
in a regular priced gasoline.
Try the Greater Fire-Chief 1 That’s all we ask.
Remember, it’s on sale at all Texaco Fire-Chief
pumps —at regular gasoline prices. Flame-Tinted
. . . for your identification and protection .
California Corporation

items.title: The day book. [volume]
note: "An adless daily newspaper."
Archived issues are available in digital format as part of the Library of Congress Chronicling America online collection.
Available on microfilm;
Description based on: Nov. 1, 1911.
Issue for <Nov. 24, 1911> lacks vol., no., and chronological designation.
Issue for Nov. 4, 1911 erroneously designated as Oct. 4, 1911.
Issue for v. 3, no. 290 (Sept. 7, 1914) erroneously designated as v. 3, no. 300 (Sept. 7, 1914). The error in numbering continues.
Issue for v. 5, no. 214 (June 7, 1916) erroneously designated as v. 5, no. 214 (June 6, 1916).
Issue for v. 5, no. 7 (Oct. 5, 1915) erroneously designated as v. 5, no. 7 (Sept. 5, 1915).
Issues for <May 7-17, 1915> called also "Moving Picture Edition."
Issues have no page numbering.

Saturdays have Noon and Final editions, Dec. 28, 1912-June 21, 1913; Saturdays have Noon and Last editions, June 28, 1913-<Dec. 13, 1913>; began issuing daily Noon and Last editions, Dec. 20, 1913-July 6, 1917.
Vol. 5, no. 36 (Nov. 6, 1915) issue called also "Garment Workers' Special Edition."
Volume numbering begins with Nov. 20, 1911 issue.
items.ocr_eng:
NEVER HAVE TO BOTHER ABOUT STARTING
THIS FIRE IT'S BEEN BURNING 200 YEARS
Cumberland, England, July 9. "I
can't remember when the kitchen
fire has ever gone out. There has
always been a fire in it ever since I
can remember, and I'm 39 years old.
My father, who lived to '75, told me
he could never remember the time
when the kitchen fire wasn't aglow,
and he also told me that his father
never saw a cold grate in the kitchen.
The family history says that the fire.

ON FEBRUARY THE 15th WE HAD A BAD FIRE IN OUR STORE, CAUSING
a large loss to our grocery and dry goods departments. The fire was confined to the
Grocery department, but we experienced a severe loss from smoke in the other department, and have made up our mind to close
out the entire stock. This is our reason for putting on the greatest merchandise sale ever held in Jamestown. We are offering to
the public our entire line of dry goods, consisting of ladies ready-to-wear garments, wash goods, hosiery, underwear, shoes, notions,
etc., staple and fancy groceries. In fact everything in our store must go in the next two weeks regardless of cost. $60,000 worth of
merchandise must be sold in this short space of time. This includes thousands of dollars worth of new spring goods, such as ladies
suits, coats, skirts, wash goods, embroideries, laces and articles too numerous to mention.
EVERYBODY IS TALKING ABOUT THIS GREAT SALE
People from far and wide are planning to attend. Our sales force will be greatly increased and we are going to try and wait on and please
everyone to the best of our ability. We are going over our stock carefully and are considering the conditions of the same in
prices. Space will not permit us to quote prices on every line of goods but we give below prices on just a few of the many bargains we have to offer

We have moved the entire salvage from our grocery department into the dry goods basement and will close
the same out to our customers at 1-2 to 1-4 the actual cost. There are hundreds of cans of fruit and bottle goods
just as good as ever. This is your opportunity to buy a big supply of groceries at your ownprice. REMEMBER
THESE GOODS ARE LIMITED AND WILL GO FAST. SO COME EARLY.
The store will be open at 8 A. M. Friday morning. We expect big crowds and are putting on a large
force of help, so as to take care of your needs as promptly as possible. Bear in mind there are thousands of
dollars worth of new spring merchandise included in this stock.
Sale Begins Friday, March 5th and Lasts for Two Weeks
